OscalArAssessmentResultsAssemblyType.title: Security Assessment Results (SAR)
OscalArAssessmentResultsAssemblyType.description: Security assessment results, such as those provided by a FedRAMP assessor in the FedRAMP Security Assessment Report.

OscalArAssessmentResultsUuidFlagType.title: Assessment Results Universally Unique Identifier
OscalArAssessmentResultsUuidFlagType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this assessment results instance in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ar-identifiers). The locally defined *UUID* of the `assessment result` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

OscalMetadataMetadataAssemblyType.title: Document Metadata
OscalMetadataMetadataAssemblyType.description:
Provides information about the containing document, and defines concepts that are shared across the document.

All OSCAL documents use the same metadata structure, that provides a consistent way of expressing OSCAL document metadata across all OSCAL models. The metadata section also includes declarations of individual objects (i.e., roles, location, parties) that may be referenced within and across linked OSCAL documents.

The metadata in an OSCAL document has few required fields, representing only the bare minimum data needed to differentiate one instance from another. Tools and users creating OSCAL documents may choose to use any of the optional fields, as well as extension mechanisms (e.g., properties, links) to go beyond this minimum to suit their use cases.

A publisher of OSCAL content can use the `published`, `last-modified`, and `version` fields to establish information about an individual in a sequence of successive revisions of a given OSCAL-based publication. The metadata for a previous revision can be represented as a `revision` within this object. Links may also be provided using the `predecessor-version` and `successor-version` link relations to provide for direct access to the related resource. These relations can be provided as a link child of this object or as `link` within a given `revision`.

A `responsible-party` entry in this context refers to roles and parties that have responsibility relative to the production, review, publication, and use of the containing document.

OscalMetadataMetadataTitleFieldType.title: Document Title
OscalMetadataMetadataTitleFieldType.description: A name given to the document, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

OscalMetadataPublishedFieldType.title: Publication Timestamp
OscalMetadataPublishedFieldType.description:
The date and time the document was last made available.

Typically, this date value will be machine-generated at the time the containing document is published.

In some cases, an OSCAL document may be derived from some source material provided in a different format. In such a case, the `published` value should indicate when the OSCAL document instance was last published, not the source material.

OscalMetadataLastModifiedFieldType.title: Last Modified Timestamp
OscalMetadataLastModifiedFieldType.description:
The date and time the document was last stored for later retrieval.

This value represents the point in time when the OSCAL document was last updated, or at the point of creation the creation date. Typically, this date value will be machine generated at time of creation or modification. Ideally, this field will be managed by the editing tool or service used to make modifications when storing the modified document.

The intent of the last modified timestamp is to distinguish between significant change milestones when the document may be accessed by multiple entities. This allows a given entity to differentiate between mutiple document states at specific points in time. It is possible to make multiple modifications to the document without storing these changes. In such a case, the last modified timestamp might not be updated until the document is finally stored.

In some cases, an OSCAL document may be derived from some source material in a different format. In such a case, the `last-modified` value should indicate the last modification time of the OSCAL document instance, not the source material.

OscalMetadataVersionFieldType.title: Document Version
OscalMetadataVersionFieldType.description:
Used to distinguish a specific revision of an OSCAL document from other previous and future versions.

A version may be a release number, sequence number, date, or other identifier sufficient to distinguish between different document revisions.

While not required, it is recommended that OSCAL content authors use [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html) as the version format. This allows for the easy identification of a version tree consisting of major, minor, and patch numbers.

A version is typically set by the document owner or by the tool used to maintain the content.

OscalMetadataOscalVersionFieldType.title: OSCAL Version
OscalMetadataOscalVersionFieldType.description:
The OSCAL model version the document was authored against and will conform to as valid.

Indicates the version of the OSCAL model to which the document conforms, for example "1.1.0" or "1.0.0-milestone1". That can be used as a hint for a tool indicating which version of the OSCAL XML or JSON schema to use for validation.

The OSCAL version serves a different purpose from the document version and is used to represent a different concept. If both have the same value, this is coincidental.

OscalMetadataMetadataRevisionAssemblyTyp.title: Revision History Entry
OscalMetadataMetadataRevisionAssemblyTyp.description:
An entry in a sequential list of revisions to the containing document, expected to be in reverse chronological order (i.e. latest first).

While `published`, `last-modified`, and `oscal-version` are not required, values for these entries should be provided if the information is known. A `link` with a `rel` of "source" should be provided if the information is known.

OscalMetadataMetadataRevisionTitleFieldT.title: Document Title
OscalMetadataMetadataRevisionTitleFieldT.description: A name given to the document revision, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

OscalMetadataPropAssemblyType.title: Property
OscalMetadataPropAssemblyType.description:
An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace qualified name/value pair.

Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order, and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure consistency.

Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context of the containing object.

OscalMetadataPropNameFlagType.title: Property Name
OscalMetadataPropNameFlagType.description: A textual label, within a namespace, that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or quality of the property's containing object.

OscalMetadataPropUuidFlagType.title: Property Universally Unique Identifier
OscalMetadataPropUuidFlagType.description: A unique identifier for a property.

OscalMetadataPropNsFlagType.title: Property Namespace
OscalMetadataPropNsFlagType.description:
A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

When a `ns` is not provided, its value should be assumed to be `http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal` and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.

OscalMetadataPropValueFlagType.title: Property Value
OscalMetadataPropValueFlagType.description: Indicates the value of the attribute, characteristic, or quality.

OscalMetadataPropClassFlagType.title: Property Class
OscalMetadataPropClassFlagType.description:
A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's `name`.

This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple properties of the same object with the same `name` and `ns`, or to group properties into categories.

A `class` can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a specific `class` value. It is available for grouping, but unlike `group` is not expected specifically to designate any group membership as such.

OscalMetadataPropGroupFlagType.title: Property Group
OscalMetadataPropGroupFlagType.description:
An identifier for relating distinct sets of properties.

Different sets of properties may relate to separate contexts. Declare a group on a property to associate it with one or more other properties in a given context.

OscalMetadataRemarksFieldType.title: Remarks
OscalMetadataRemarksFieldType.description:
Additional commentary about the containing object.

The `remarks` field SHOULD not be used to store arbitrary data. Instead, a `prop` or `link` should be used to annotate or reference any additional data not formally supported by OSCAL.

OscalMetadataLinkAssemblyType.title: Link
OscalMetadataLinkAssemblyType.description:
A reference to a local or remote resource, that has a specific relation to the containing object.

To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to a back matter `resource` is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the `rlink/hash` object.

The OSCAL `link` is a roughly based on the HTML [link element](https://www.w3.org/TR/html401/struct/links.html#edef-LINK).

OscalMetadataLinkHrefFlagType.title: Hypertext Reference
OscalMetadataLinkHrefFlagType.description:
A resolvable URL reference to a resource.

This value may be one of:

1. an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that points to a network resolvable resource,
2. a [relative reference](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#relative-reference) pointing to a network resolvable resource whose base URI is the URI of the containing document, or
3. a bare URI fragment (i.e., \`#uuid\`) pointing to an OSCAL object by the objects identifier (e.g., id, uuid) in this or an imported document (see [linking to another OSCAL object](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#linking-to-another-oscal-object)). The specific object type will differ based on the link relationship type.

OscalMetadataLinkRelFlagType.title: Link Relation Type
OscalMetadataLinkRelFlagType.description: Describes the type of relationship provided by the link's hypertext reference. This can be an indicator of the link's purpose.

OscalMetadataMediaTypeFlagType.title: Media Type
OscalMetadataMediaTypeFlagType.description:
A label that indicates the nature of a resource, as a data serialization or format.

The Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) [Media
Types Registry](https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml) defines a standardized set of media types, which may be used
here.

The `application/oscal+xml`, `application/oscal+json` or `application/oscal+yaml` media types SHOULD be used when referencing OSCAL XML, JSON, or YAML resources respectively.

\*\*Note: There is no official media type for YAML at this time.\*\* OSCAL documents should specify `application/yaml` for general YAML content, or `application/oscal+yaml` for YAML-based OSCAL content. This approach aligns with use of a structured name suffix, per [RFC 6838 Section 4.2.8](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6838.html#section-4.2.8).

Some earlier OSCAL content incorporated the model into the media type. For example: `application/oscal.catalog+xml`. This practice SHOULD be avoided, since the OSCAL model can be detected by parsing the initial content of the referenced resource.

OscalMetadataLinkResourceFragmentFlagTyp.title: Resource Fragment
OscalMetadataLinkResourceFragmentFlagTyp.description: In case where the `href` points to a `back-matter/resource`, this value will indicate the URI [fragment](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-3.5) to append to any `rlink` associated with the resource. This value MUST be [URI encoded](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986#section-2.1).

OscalMetadataLinkTextFieldType.title: Link Text
OscalMetadataLinkTextFieldType.description: A textual label to associate with the link, which may be used for presentation in a tool.

OscalMetadataDocumentIdFieldType.title: Document Identifier
OscalMetadataDocumentIdFieldType.description:
A document identifier qualified by an identifier `scheme`.

A document identifier provides a [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with a [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that is used for a group of documents that are to be treated as different versions, representations or digital surrogates of the same document.

A document identifier provides an additional data point for identifying a document that can be assigned by a publisher or organization for purposes in a wider system, such as a digital object identifier (DOI) or a local content management system identifier.

Use of a document identifier allows for document creators to associate sets of documents that are related in some way by the same `document-id`.

An OSCAL document always has an implicit document identifier provided by the document's UUID, defined by the `uuid` on the top-level object. Having a default UUID-based identifier ensures all documents can be minimally identified when other document identifiers are not provided.

OscalMetadataDocumentIdSchemeFlagType.title: Document Identification Scheme
OscalMetadataDocumentIdSchemeFlagType.description:
Qualifies the kind of document identifier using a URI. If the scheme is not provided the value of the element will be interpreted as a string of characters.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

OscalMetadataMetadataRoleAssemblyType.title: Role
OscalMetadataMetadataRoleAssemblyType.description:
Defines a function, which might be assigned to a party in a specific situation.

Permissible values to be determined closer to the application (e.g. by a receiving authority).

OSCAL has defined a set of standardized roles for consistent use in OSCAL documents. This allows tools consuming OSCAL content to infer specific semantics when these roles are used. These roles are documented in the specific contexts of their use (e.g., responsible-party, responsible-role). When using such a role, it is necessary to define these roles in this list, which will then allow such a role to be referenced.

OscalMetadataMetadataRoleIdFlagType.title: Role Identifier
OscalMetadataMetadataRoleIdFlagType.description: A unique identifier for the role.

OscalMetadataMetadataRoleTitleFieldType.title: Role Title
OscalMetadataMetadataRoleTitleFieldType.description: A name given to the role, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

OscalMetadataMetadataRoleShortNameFieldT.title: Role Short Name
OscalMetadataMetadataRoleShortNameFieldT.description: A short common name, abbreviation, or acronym for the role.

OscalMetadataMetadataRoleDescriptionFiel.title: Role Description
OscalMetadataMetadataRoleDescriptionFiel.description: A summary of the role's purpose and associated responsibilities.

OscalMetadataMetadataLocationAssemblyTyp.title: Location
OscalMetadataMetadataLocationAssemblyTyp.description:
A physical point of presence, which may be associated with people, organizations, or other concepts within the current or linked OSCAL document.

An address might be sensitive in nature. In such cases a title, mailing address, email-address, and/or phone number may be used instead.

OscalMetadataMetadataLocationUuidFlagTyp.title: Location Universally Unique Identifier
OscalMetadataMetadataLocationUuidFlagTyp.description: A unique ID for the location, for reference.

OscalMetadataMetadataLocationTitleFieldT.title: Location Title
OscalMetadataMetadataLocationTitleFieldT.description: A name given to the location, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

OscalMetadataAddressAssemblyType.title: Address
OscalMetadataAddressAssemblyType.description: A postal address for the location.

OscalMetadataAddrLineFieldType.title: Address line
OscalMetadataAddrLineFieldType.description: A single line of an address.

OscalMetadataAddressCityFieldType.title: City
OscalMetadataAddressCityFieldType.description: City, town or geographical region for the mailing address.

OscalMetadataAddressStateFieldType.title: State
OscalMetadataAddressStateFieldType.description: State, province or analogous geographical region for a mailing address.

OscalMetadataAddressPostalCodeFieldType.title: Postal Code
OscalMetadataAddressPostalCodeFieldType.description: Postal or ZIP code for mailing address.

OscalMetadataAddressCountryFieldType.title: Country Code
OscalMetadataAddressCountryFieldType.description: The ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code for the mailing address.

OscalMetadataEmailAddressFieldType.title: Email Address
OscalMetadataEmailAddressFieldType.description:
An email address as defined by [RFC 5322 Section
3.4.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5322#section-3.4.1).

OscalMetadataTelephoneNumberFieldType.title: Telephone Number
OscalMetadataTelephoneNumberFieldType.description: A telephone service number as defined by [ITU-T E.164](https://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-E.164-201011-I/en).

OscalMetadataTelephoneNumberTypeFlagType.title: type flag
OscalMetadataTelephoneNumberTypeFlagType.description: Indicates the type of phone number.

OscalMetadataMetadataLocationUrlFieldTyp.title: Location URL
OscalMetadataMetadataLocationUrlFieldTyp.description:
The uniform resource locator (URL) for a web site or other resource associated with the location.

This data field is deprecated in favor of using a link with an appropriate relationship.

OscalMetadataMetadataPartyAssemblyType.title: Party
OscalMetadataMetadataPartyAssemblyType.description:
An organization or person, which may be associated with roles or other concepts within the current or linked OSCAL document.

A party can be optionally associated with either an address or a location. While providing a meaningful location for a party is desired, there are some cases where it might not be possible to provide an exact location or even any location.

OscalMetadataMetadataPartyUuidFlagType.title: Party Universally Unique Identifier
OscalMetadataMetadataPartyUuidFlagType.description: A unique identifier for the party.

OscalMetadataMetadataPartyTypeFlagType.title: Party Type
OscalMetadataMetadataPartyTypeFlagType.description: A category describing the kind of party the object describes.

OscalMetadataMetadataPartyNameFieldType.title: Party Name
OscalMetadataMetadataPartyNameFieldType.description: The full name of the party. This is typically the legal name associated with the party.

OscalMetadataMetadataPartyShortNameField.title: Party Short Name
OscalMetadataMetadataPartyShortNameField.description: A short common name, abbreviation, or acronym for the party.

OscalMetadataMetadataPartyExternalIdFiel.title: Party External Identifier
OscalMetadataMetadataPartyExternalIdFiel.description: An identifier for a person or organization using a designated scheme. e.g. an Open Researcher and Contributor ID (ORCID).

OscalMetadataMetadataPartyExternalIdSche.title: External Identifier Schema
OscalMetadataMetadataPartyExternalIdSche.description:
Indicates the type of external identifier.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

OscalMetadataLocationUuidFieldType.title: Location Universally Unique Identifier Reference
OscalMetadataLocationUuidFieldType.description: Reference to a location by UUID.

OscalMetadataMetadataPartyMemberOfOrgani.title: Organizational Affiliation
OscalMetadataMetadataPartyMemberOfOrgani.description:
A reference to another `party` by UUID, typically an organization, that this subject is associated with.

Since the reference target of an organizational affiliation must be another `party` (whether further qualified as person or organization) as inidcated by its `uuid`. As a [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier with uniqueness across document and trans-document scope, this `uuid` value is sufficient to reference the data item locally or globally across related documents, e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance.

Parties of both the `person` or `organization` type can be associated with an organization using the `member-of-organization`.

OscalMetadataResponsiblePartyAssemblyTyp.title: Responsible Party
OscalMetadataResponsiblePartyAssemblyTyp.description:
A reference to a set of persons and/or organizations that have responsibility for performing the referenced role in the context of the containing object.

A `responsible-party` requires one or more `party-uuid` references creating a strong relationship arc between the referenced `role-id` and the reference parties. This differs in semantics from `responsible-role` which doesn't require that a `party-uuid` is referenced.

The scope of use of this object determines if the responsibility has been performed or will be performed in the future. The containing object will describe the intent.

OscalMetadataResponsiblePartyRoleIdFlagT.title: Responsible Role
OscalMetadataResponsiblePartyRoleIdFlagT.description: A reference to a `role` performed by a `party`.

OscalMetadataPartyUuidFieldType.title: Party Universally Unique Identifier Reference
OscalMetadataPartyUuidFieldType.description: Reference to a party by UUID.

OscalMetadataActionAssemblyType.title: Action
OscalMetadataActionAssemblyType.description: An action applied by a role within a given party to the content.

OscalMetadataActionUuidFlagType.title: Action Universally Unique Identifier
OscalMetadataActionUuidFlagType.description: A unique identifier that can be used to reference this defined action elsewhere in an OSCAL document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions of the document.

OscalMetadataActionDateFlagType.title: Action Occurrence Date
OscalMetadataActionDateFlagType.description: The date and time when the action occurred.

OscalMetadataActionTypeFlagType.title: Action Type
OscalMetadataActionTypeFlagType.description: The type of action documented by the assembly, such as an approval.

OscalMetadataActionSystemFlagType.title: Action Type System
OscalMetadataActionSystemFlagType.description:
Specifies the action type system used.

Provides a means to segment the value space for the `type`, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed `action`'s `type`. This allows the semantics associated with a given `type` to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.

An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.

OscalArImportApAssemblyType.title: Import Assessment Plan
OscalArImportApAssemblyType.description: Used by assessment-results to import information about the original plan for assessing the system.

OscalArImportApHrefFlagType.title: Assessment Plan Reference
OscalArImportApHrefFlagType.description:
A resolvable URL reference to the assessment plan governing the assessment activities.

This value may be one of:

1. an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that points to a network resolvable resource,
2. a [relative reference](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#relative-reference) pointing to a network resolvable resource whose base URI is the URI of the containing document, or
3. a bare URI fragment (i.e., \`#uuid\`) pointing to a `back-matter` resource in this or an imported document (see [linking to another OSCAL object](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#linking-to-another-oscal-object)).

OscalArAssessmentResultsLocalDefinitions.title: Local Definitions
OscalArAssessmentResultsLocalDefinitions.description: Used to define data objects that are used in the assessment plan, that do not appear in the referenced SSP.

OscalAssessmentCommonLocalObjectiveAssem.title: Assessment-Specific Control Objective
OscalAssessmentCommonLocalObjectiveAssem.description: A local definition of a control objective for this assessment. Uses catalog syntax for control objective and assessment actions.

OscalControlCommonControlIdFlagType.title: Control Identifier Reference
OscalControlCommonControlIdFlagType.description: A reference to a control with a corresponding `id` value. When referencing an externally defined `control`, the `Control Identifier Reference` must be used in the context of the external / imported OSCAL instance (e.g., uri-reference).

OscalAssessmentCommonLocalObjectiveDescr.title: Objective Description
OscalAssessmentCommonLocalObjectiveDescr.description: A human-readable description of this control objective.

OscalControlCommonPartAssemblyType.title: Part
OscalControlCommonPartAssemblyType.description:
An annotated, markup-based textual element of a control's or catalog group's definition, or a child of another part.

A `part` provides for logical partitioning of prose, and can be thought of as a grouping structure (e.g., section). A `part` can have child parts allowing for arbitrary nesting of prose content (e.g., statement hierarchy). A `part` can contain `prop` objects that allow for enriching prose text with structured name/value information.

A `part` can be assigned an optional `id`, which allows references to this part from within a catalog, or within an instance of another OSCAL model that has a need to reference the part. Examples of where part referencing is used in OSCAL include:

* Referencing a part by id to tailor (make modifications to) a control statement in a profile.
* Referencing a control statement represented by a part in a system security plan implemented-requirement where a statement-level response is desired.

Use of `part` and `prop` provides for a wide degree of extensibility within the OSCAL catalog model. The optional `ns` provides a means to qualify a part's `name`, allowing for organization-specific vocabularies to be defined with clear semantics. Any organization that extends OSCAL in this way should consistently assign a `ns` value that represents the organization, making a given namespace qualified `name` unique to that organization. This allows the combination of `ns` and `name` to always be unique and unambiguous, even when mixed with extensions from other organizations. Each organization is responsible for governance of their own extensions, and is strongly encouraged to publish their extensions as standards to their user community. If no `ns` is provided, the name is expected to be in the "OSCAL" namespace.

To ensure a `ns` is unique to an organization and naming conflicts are avoided, a URI containing a DNS or other globally defined organization name should be used. For example, if FedRAMP and DoD both extend OSCAL, FedRAMP will use the `ns` `http://fedramp.gov/ns/oscal`, while DoD might use the `ns` `https://defense.gov` for any organization specific `name`.

Tools that process OSCAL content are not required to interpret unrecognized OSCAL extensions; however, OSCAL compliant tools should not modify or remove unrecognized extensions, unless there is a compelling reason to do so, such as data sensitivity.

OscalControlCommonPartIdFlagType.title: Part Identifier
OscalControlCommonPartIdFlagType.description:
A unique identifier for the part.

While a part is not required to have an id, it is often desirable for an identifier to be provided, which allows the part to be referenced elsewhere in OSCAL document instances. For this reason, it is RECOMMENDED to provide a part identifier.

OscalControlCommonPartNameFlagType.title: Part Name
OscalControlCommonPartNameFlagType.description: A textual label that uniquely identifies the part's semantic type, which exists in a value space qualified by the `ns`.

OscalControlCommonPartNsFlagType.title: Part Namespace
OscalControlCommonPartNsFlagType.description:
An optional namespace qualifying the part's `name`. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

When a `ns` is not provided, its value should be assumed to be `http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal` and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.

OscalControlCommonPartClassFlagType.title: Part Class
OscalControlCommonPartClassFlagType.description:
An optional textual providing a sub-type or characterization of the part's `name`, or a category to which the part belongs.

One use of this flag is to distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple parts of the same control with the same `name` and `ns` (since even within a given namespace it can be useful to overload a name).

A `class` can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a specific `class` value.

A `class` can also be used in an OSCAL profile as a means to target an alteration to control content.

OscalControlCommonPartTitleFieldType.title: Part Title
OscalControlCommonPartTitleFieldType.description: An optional name given to the part, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

OscalControlCommonPartProseFieldType.title: Part Text
OscalControlCommonPartProseFieldType.description: Permits multiple paragraphs, lists, tables etc.

OscalAssessmentCommonActivityAssemblyTyp.title: Activity
OscalAssessmentCommonActivityAssemblyTyp.description: Identifies an assessment or related process that can be performed. In the assessment plan, this is an intended activity which may be associated with an assessment task. In the assessment results, this an activity that was actually performed as part of an assessment.

OscalAssessmentCommonActivityUuidFlagTyp.title: Assessment Activity Universally Unique Identifier
OscalAssessmentCommonActivityUuidFlagTyp.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this assessment activity elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). The locally defined *UUID* of the `activity` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

OscalAssessmentCommonActivityTitleFieldT.title: Included Activity Title
OscalAssessmentCommonActivityTitleFieldT.description: The title for this included activity.

OscalAssessmentCommonActivityDescription.title: Included Activity Description
OscalAssessmentCommonActivityDescription.description: A human-readable description of this included activity.

OscalAssessmentCommonActivityStepAssembl.title: Step
OscalAssessmentCommonActivityStepAssembl.description: Identifies an individual step in a series of steps related to an activity, such as an assessment test or examination procedure.

OscalAssessmentCommonActivityStepUuidFla.title: Step Universally Unique Identifier
OscalAssessmentCommonActivityStepUuidFla.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this step elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). The locally defined *UUID* of the `step` (in a series of steps) can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

OscalAssessmentCommonActivityStepDescrip.title: Step Description
OscalAssessmentCommonActivityStepDescrip.description: A human-readable description of this step.

OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsAss.title: Reviewed Controls and Control Objectives
OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsAss.description:
Identifies the controls being assessed and their control objectives.

In the context of an assessment plan, this construct is used to identify the controls and control objectives that are to be assessed. In the context of an assessment result, this construct is used to identify the actual controls and objectives that were assessed, reflecting any changes from the plan.

When resolving the selection of controls and control objectives, the following processing will occur:

1. Controls will be resolved by creating a set of controls based on the control-selections by first handling the includes, and then removing any excluded controls.

2. The set of control objectives will be resolved from the set of controls that was generated in the previous step. The set of control objectives is based on the control-objective-selection by first handling the includes, and then removing any excluded control objectives.

OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsDes.title: Control Objective Description
OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsDes.description: A human-readable description of control objectives.

OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsCon.title: Assessed Controls
OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsCon.description:
Identifies the controls being assessed. In the assessment plan, these are the planned controls. In the assessment results, these are the actual controls, and reflects any changes from the plan.

The `include-all`, specifies all control identified in the **baseline** are included in the scope if this assessment, as specified by the `include-profile` statement within the linked SSP.

Any control specified within `exclude-controls` must first be within a range of explicitly included controls, via `include-controls` or `include-all`.

OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsCon.title: Assessed Controls Description
OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsCon.description: A human-readable description of in-scope controls specified for assessment.

OscalControlCommonIncludeAllAssemblyType.title: Include All
OscalControlCommonIncludeAllAssemblyType.description:
Include all controls from the imported catalog or profile resources.

This element provides an alternative to calling controls individually from a catalog.

OscalAssessmentCommonSelectControlByIdAs.title: Select Control
OscalAssessmentCommonSelectControlByIdAs.description: Used to select a control for inclusion/exclusion based on one or more control identifiers. A set of statement identifiers can be used to target the inclusion/exclusion to only specific control statements providing more granularity over the specific statements that are within the asessment scope.

OscalAssessmentCommonSelectControlByIdSt.title: Include Specific Statements
OscalAssessmentCommonSelectControlByIdSt.description: Used to constrain the selection to only specificity identified statements.

OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsCon.title: Referenced Control Objectives
OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsCon.description:
Identifies the control objectives of the assessment. In the assessment plan, these are the planned objectives. In the assessment results, these are the assessed objectives, and reflects any changes from the plan.

The `include-all` field, specifies all control objectives for any in-scope control. In-scope controls are defined in the `control-selection`.

Any control objective specified within `exclude-controls` must first be within a range of explicitly included control objectives, via `include-objectives` or `include-all`.

OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsCon.title: Control Objectives Description
OscalAssessmentCommonReviewedControlsCon.description: A human-readable description of this collection of control objectives.

OscalAssessmentCommonSelectObjectiveById.title: Select Objective
OscalAssessmentCommonSelectObjectiveById.description: Used to select a control objective for inclusion/exclusion based on the control objective's identifier.

OscalMetadataResponsibleRoleAssemblyType.title: Responsible Role
OscalMetadataResponsibleRoleAssemblyType.description:
A reference to a role with responsibility for performing a function relative to the containing object, optionally associated with a set of persons and/or organizations that perform that role.

A `responsible-role` allows zero or more `party-uuid` references, each of which creates a relationship arc between the referenced `role-id` and the referenced party. This differs in semantics from `responsible-party`, which requires that at least one `party-uuid` is referenced.

The scope of use of this object determines if the responsibility has been performed or will be performed in the future. The containing object will describe the intent.

The `type` indicates which of these component types is represented.

When defining a `service` component where are relationship to other components is known, one or more `link` entries with rel values of provided-by and used-by can be used to link to the specific component identifier(s) that provide and use the service respectively.

OscalAssessmentCommonPartAssemblyType.title: Assessment Part
OscalAssessmentCommonPartAssemblyType.description:
A partition of an assessment plan or results or a child of another part.

A `part` provides for logical partitioning of prose, and can be thought of as a grouping structure (e.g., section). A `part` can have child parts allowing for arbitrary nesting of prose content (e.g., statement hierarchy). A `part` can contain `prop` objects that allow for enriching prose text with structured name/value information.

A `part` can be assigned an optional `id`, which allows for internal and external references to the textual concept contained within a `part`. A `id` provides a means for an OSCAL profile, or a higher layer OSCAL model to reference a specific part within a `catalog`. For example, an `id` can be used to reference or to make modifications to a control statement in a profile.

Use of `part` and `prop` provides for a wide degree of extensibility within the OSCAL catalog model. The optional `ns` provides a means to qualify a part's `name`, allowing for organization-specific vocabularies to be defined with clear semantics. Any organization that extends OSCAL in this way should consistently assign a `ns` value that represents the organization, making a given namespace qualified `name` unique to that organization. This allows the combination of `ns` and `name` to always be unique and unambiguous, even when mixed with extensions from other organizations. Each organization is responsible for governance of their own extensions, and is strongly encouraged to publish their extensions as standards to their user community. If no `ns` is provided, the name is expected to be in the "OSCAL" namespace.

To ensure a `ns` is unique to an organization and naming conflicts are avoided, a URI containing a DNS or other globally defined organization name should be used. For example, if FedRAMP and DoD both extend OSCAL, FedRAMP will use the `ns` `http://fedramp.gov/ns/oscal`, while DoD might use the `ns` `https://defense.gov` for any organization specific `name`.

Tools that process OSCAL content are not required to interpret unrecognized OSCAL extensions; however, OSCAL compliant tools should not modify or remove unrecognized extensions, unless there is a compelling reason to do so, such as data sensitivity.

OscalAssessmentCommonPartUuidFlagType.title: Part Identifier
OscalAssessmentCommonPartUuidFlagType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this part elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). The locally defined *UUID* of the `part` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an ported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

OscalAssessmentCommonPartNameFlagType.title: Part Name
OscalAssessmentCommonPartNameFlagType.description: A textual label that uniquely identifies the part's semantic type.

OscalAssessmentCommonPartNsFlagType.title: Part Namespace
OscalAssessmentCommonPartNsFlagType.description:
A namespace qualifying the part's name. This allows different organizations to associate distinct semantics with the same name.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

When a `ns` is not provided, its value should be assumed to be `http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal` and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.

OscalAssessmentCommonPartClassFlagType.title: Part Class
OscalAssessmentCommonPartClassFlagType.description:
A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the part's `name`. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of multiple parts of the same control with the same `name` and `ns`.

A `class` can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a specific `class` value.

A `class` can also be used in an OSCAL profile as a means to target an alteration to control content.

OscalAssessmentCommonPartTitleFieldType.description: A name given to the part, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

OscalAssessmentCommonPartProseFieldType.description: Permits multiple paragraphs, lists, tables etc.

OscalAssessmentCommonLoggedByPartyUuidFl.title: Party UUID Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonLoggedByPartyUuidFl.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to the party who is making the log entry.

OscalAssessmentCommonLoggedByRoleIdFlagT.title: Actor Role
OscalAssessmentCommonLoggedByRoleIdFlagT.description: A point to the role-id of the role in which the party is making the log entry.

OscalAssessmentCommonRelatedTaskAssembly.title: Task Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonRelatedTaskAssembly.description: Identifies an individual task for which the containing object is a consequence of.

OscalAssessmentCommonRelatedTaskTaskUuid.title: Task Universally Unique Identifier Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonRelatedTaskTaskUuid.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to a unique task.

OscalAssessmentCommonRelatedTaskIdentifi.title: Identified Subject
OscalAssessmentCommonRelatedTaskIdentifi.description: Used to detail assessment subjects that were identfied by this task.

OscalAssessmentCommonRelatedTaskIdentifi.title: Assessment Subject Placeholder Universally Unique Identifier Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonRelatedTaskIdentifi.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to a unique assessment subject placeholder defined by this task.

OscalAssessmentCommonObservationUuidFlag.title: Observation Universally Unique Identifier
OscalAssessmentCommonObservationUuidFlag.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with *cross-instance* scope that can be used to reference this observation elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). The locally defined *UUID* of the `observation` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imorted OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

OscalAssessmentCommonObservationDescript.title: Observation Description
OscalAssessmentCommonObservationDescript.description: A human-readable description of this assessment observation.

OscalAssessmentCommonObservationMethodFi.title: Observation Method
OscalAssessmentCommonObservationMethodFi.description: Identifies how the observation was made.

OscalAssessmentCommonObservationTypeFiel.title: Observation Type
OscalAssessmentCommonObservationTypeFiel.description: Identifies the nature of the observation. More than one may be used to further qualify and enable filtering.

OscalAssessmentCommonOriginAssemblyType.title: Origin
OscalAssessmentCommonOriginAssemblyType.description: Identifies the source of the finding, such as a tool, interviewed person, or activity.

OscalAssessmentCommonOriginActorAssembly.title: Originating Actor
OscalAssessmentCommonOriginActorAssembly.description: The actor that produces an observation, a finding, or a risk. One or more actor type can be used to specify a person that is using a tool.

OscalAssessmentCommonOriginActorActorUui.title: Actor Universally Unique Identifier Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonOriginActorActorUui.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to the tool or person based on the associated type.

OscalAssessmentCommonOriginActorRoleIdFl.title: Actor Role
OscalAssessmentCommonOriginActorRoleIdFl.description: For a party, this can optionally be used to specify the role the actor was performing.

OscalAssessmentCommonSubjectReferenceAss.title: Identifies the Subject
OscalAssessmentCommonSubjectReferenceAss.description:
A [human-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#human-oriented) identifier reference to a resource. Use type to indicate whether the identified resource is a component, inventory item, location, user, or something else.

The subject reference UUID could point to an item defined in the SSP, AP, or AR.

Tools should check look for the ID in every file imported directly or indirectly.

OscalAssessmentCommonSubjectReferenceTit.title: Subject Reference Title
OscalAssessmentCommonSubjectReferenceTit.description: The title or name for the referenced subject.

OscalAssessmentCommonObservationRelevant.title: Relevant Evidence
OscalAssessmentCommonObservationRelevant.description: Links this observation to relevant evidence.

OscalAssessmentCommonObservationRelevant.title: Relevant Evidence Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonObservationRelevant.description:
A resolvable URL reference to relevant evidence.

This value may be one of:

1. an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that points to a network resolvable resource,
2. a [relative reference](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#relative-reference) pointing to a network resolvable resource whose base URI is the URI of the containing document, or
3. a bare URI fragment (i.e., \`#uuid\`) pointing to a `back-matter` resource in this or an imported document (see [linking to another OSCAL object](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#linking-to-another-oscal-object)).

OscalAssessmentCommonObservationRelevant.title: Relevant Evidence Description
OscalAssessmentCommonObservationRelevant.description: A human-readable description of this evidence.

OscalAssessmentCommonObservationCollecte.title: Collected Field
OscalAssessmentCommonObservationCollecte.description: Date/time stamp identifying when the finding information was collected.

OscalAssessmentCommonObservationExpiresF.title: Expires Field
OscalAssessmentCommonObservationExpiresF.description: Date/time identifying when the finding information is out-of-date and no longer valid. Typically used with continuous assessment scenarios.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskUuidFlagType.title: Risk Universally Unique Identifier
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskUuidFlagType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this risk elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). The locally defined *UUID* of the `risk` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskDescriptionFiel.title: Risk Description
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskDescriptionFiel.description: A human-readable summary of the identified risk, to include a statement of how the risk impacts the system.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskStatementFieldT.title: Risk Statement
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskStatementFieldT.description: An summary of impact for how the risk affects the system.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskStatusFieldType.title: Risk Status
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskStatusFieldType.description: Describes the status of the associated risk.

OscalAssessmentCommonThreatIdFieldType.title: Threat ID
OscalAssessmentCommonThreatIdFieldType.description: A pointer, by ID, to an externally-defined threat.

OscalAssessmentCommonThreatIdSystemFlagT.title: Threat Type Identification System
OscalAssessmentCommonThreatIdSystemFlagT.description:
Specifies the source of the threat information.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

OscalAssessmentCommonThreatIdHrefFlagTyp.title: Threat Information Resource Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonThreatIdHrefFlagTyp.description:
An optional location for the threat data, from which this ID originates.

This value may be one of:

1. an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that points to a network resolvable resource,
2. a [relative reference](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#relative-reference) pointing to a network resolvable resource whose base URI is the URI of the containing document, or
3. a bare URI fragment (i.e., \`#uuid\`) pointing to a `back-matter` resource in this or an imported document (see [linking to another OSCAL object](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#linking-to-another-oscal-object)).

OscalAssessmentCommonCharacterizationAss.title: Characterization
OscalAssessmentCommonCharacterizationAss.description: A collection of descriptive data about the containing object from a specific origin.

OscalAssessmentCommonCharacterizationFac.title: Facet
OscalAssessmentCommonCharacterizationFac.description: An individual characteristic that is part of a larger set produced by the same actor.

OscalAssessmentCommonCharacterizationFac.title: Facet Name
OscalAssessmentCommonCharacterizationFac.description: The name of the risk metric within the specified system.

OscalAssessmentCommonCharacterizationFac.title: Naming System
OscalAssessmentCommonCharacterizationFac.description:
Specifies the naming system under which this risk metric is organized, which allows for the same names to be used in different systems controlled by different parties. This avoids the potential of a name clash.

This value must be an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that serves as a [naming system identifier](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#use-as-a-naming-system-identifier).

OscalAssessmentCommonCharacterizationFac.title: Facet Value
OscalAssessmentCommonCharacterizationFac.description: Indicates the value of the facet.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskMitigatingFacto.title: Mitigating Factor
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskMitigatingFacto.description: Describes an existing mitigating factor that may affect the overall determination of the risk, with an optional link to an implementation statement in the SSP.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskMitigatingFacto.title: Mitigating Factor Universally Unique Identifier
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskMitigatingFacto.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this mitigating factor elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). The locally defined *UUID* of the `mitigating factor` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskMitigatingFacto.title: Implementation UUID
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskMitigatingFacto.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this implementation statement elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope)s. The locally defined *UUID* of the `implementation statement` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskMitigatingFacto.title: Mitigating Factor Description
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskMitigatingFacto.description: A human-readable description of this mitigating factor.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskDeadlineFieldTy.title: Risk Resolution Deadline
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskDeadlineFieldTy.description: The date/time by which the risk must be resolved.

OscalAssessmentCommonResponseAssemblyTyp.title: Risk Response
OscalAssessmentCommonResponseAssemblyTyp.description: Describes either recommended or an actual plan for addressing the risk.

OscalAssessmentCommonResponseUuidFlagTyp.title: Remediation Universally Unique Identifier
OscalAssessmentCommonResponseUuidFlagTyp.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this remediation elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

OscalAssessmentCommonResponseLifecycleFl.title: Remediation Intent
OscalAssessmentCommonResponseLifecycleFl.description: Identifies whether this is a recommendation, such as from an assessor or tool, or an actual plan accepted by the system owner.

OscalAssessmentCommonResponseTitleFieldT.title: Response Title
OscalAssessmentCommonResponseTitleFieldT.description: The title for this response activity.

OscalAssessmentCommonResponseDescription.title: Response Description
OscalAssessmentCommonResponseDescription.description: A human-readable description of this response plan.

OscalAssessmentCommonResponseRequiredAss.title: Required Asset
OscalAssessmentCommonResponseRequiredAss.description: Identifies an asset required to achieve remediation.

OscalAssessmentCommonResponseRequiredAss.title: Required Universally Unique Identifier
OscalAssessmentCommonResponseRequiredAss.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this required asset elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). OscalAssessmentCommonResponseRequiredAss.title: Title for Required Asset
OscalAssessmentCommonResponseRequiredAss.description: The title for this required asset.

OscalAssessmentCommonResponseRequiredAss.title: Description of Required Asset
OscalAssessmentCommonResponseRequiredAss.description: A human-readable description of this required asset.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogAssembly.title: Risk Log
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogAssembly.description: A log of all risk-related tasks taken.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryAss.title: Risk Log Entry
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryAss.description: Identifies an individual risk response that occurred as part of managing an identified risk.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryUui.title: Risk Log Entry Universally Unique Identifier
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryUui.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this risk log entry elsewhere in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#scope). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryTit.title: Title
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryTit.description: The title for this risk log entry.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryDes.title: Risk Task Description
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryDes.description: A human-readable description of what was done regarding the risk.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntrySta.title: Start
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntrySta.description: Identifies the start date and time of the event.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryEnd.title: End
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryEnd.description: Identifies the end date and time of the event. If the event is a point in time, the start and end will be the same date and time.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryRel.title: Risk Response Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryRel.description: Identifies an individual risk response that this log entry is for.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryRel.title: Response Universally Unique Identifier Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRiskLogEntryRel.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to a unique risk response.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRelatedObservat.title: Related Observation
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRelatedObservat.description: Relates the finding to a set of referenced observations that were used to determine the finding.

OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRelatedObservat.title: Observation Universally Unique Identifier Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonRiskRelatedObservat.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to an observation defined in the list of observations.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingUuidFlagType.title: Finding Universally Unique Identifier
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingUuidFlagType.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented), [globally unique](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#globally-unique) identifier with [cross-instance](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#cross-instance) scope that can be used to reference this finding in [this or other OSCAL instances](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#ar-identifiers). The locally defined *UUID* of the `finding` can be used to reference the data item locally or globally (e.g., in an imported OSCAL instance). This UUID should be assigned [per-subject](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#consistency), which means it should be consistently used to identify the same subject across revisions of the document.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingDescriptionF.title: Finding Description
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingDescriptionF.description: A human-readable description of this finding.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetAssemb.title: Objective Status
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetAssemb.description: Captures an assessor's conclusions regarding the degree to which an objective is satisfied.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetTypeFl.title: Finding Target Type
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetTypeFl.description:
Identifies the type of the target.

The target will always be a reference to: 1) a control statement, or 2) a control objective. In the former case, there is always a single top-level statement within a control. Thus, if the entire control is targeted, this statement identifier can be used.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetTarget.title: Finding Target Identifier Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetTarget.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference for a specific target qualified by the `type`.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetTitleF.title: Objective Status Title
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetTitleF.description: The title for this objective status.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetDescri.title: Objective Status Description
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetDescri.description: A human-readable description of the assessor's conclusions regarding the degree to which an objective is satisfied.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetStatus.title: Objective Status
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetStatus.description: A determination of if the objective is satisfied or not within a given system.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetStatus.title: Objective Status State
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetStatus.description: An indication as to whether the objective is satisfied or not.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetStatus.title: Objective Status Reason
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingTargetStatus.description:
The reason the objective was given it's status.

Reason may contain any value, and should be used to communicate additional information regarding the status.

OscalImplementationCommonImplementationS.title: Implementation Status
OscalImplementationCommonImplementationS.description: Indicates the degree to which the a given control is implemented.

OscalImplementationCommonImplementationS.title: Implementation State
OscalImplementationCommonImplementationS.description: Identifies the implementation status of the control or control objective.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingImplementati.title: Implementation Statement UUID
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingImplementati.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to the implementation statement in the SSP to which this finding is related.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingRelatedObser.title: Related Observation
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingRelatedObser.description: Relates the finding to a set of referenced observations that were used to determine the finding.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingRelatedObser.title: Observation Universally Unique Identifier Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingRelatedObser.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to an observation defined in the list of observations.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingAssociatedRi.title: Associated Risk
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingAssociatedRi.description: Relates the finding to a set of referenced risks that were used to determine the finding.

OscalAssessmentCommonFindingAssociatedRi.title: Risk Universally Unique Identifier Reference
OscalAssessmentCommonFindingAssociatedRi.description: A [machine-oriented](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/identifier-use/#machine-oriented) identifier reference to a risk defined in the list of risks.

OscalMetadataBackMatterAssemblyType.title: Back matter
OscalMetadataBackMatterAssemblyType.description:
A collection of resources that may be referenced from within the OSCAL document instance.

Provides a collection of identified `resource` objects that can be referenced by a `link` with a `rel` value of "reference" and an `href` value that is a fragment "#" followed by a reference to a reference's `uuid`. Other specialized link "rel" values also use this pattern when indicated in that context of use.

OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceAssemblyT.title: Resource
OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceAssemblyT.description:
A resource associated with content in the containing document instance. A resource may be directly included in the document using base64 encoding or may point to one or more equivalent internet resources.

A resource can be used in two ways. 1) it may point to an specific retrievable network resource using a `rlink`, or 2) it may be included as an attachment using a `base64`. A resource may contain multiple `rlink` and `base64` entries that represent alternative download locations (rlink) and attachments (base64) for the same resource.

Both rlink and base64 allow for a `media-type` to be specified, which is used to distinguish between different representations of the same resource (e.g., Microsoft Word, PDF). When multiple `rlink` and `base64` items are included for a given resource, all items must contain equivalent information. This allows the document consumer to choose a preferred item to process based on a the selected item's `media-type`. This is extremely important when the items represent OSCAL content that is represented in alternate formats (i.e., XML, JSON, YAML), allowing the same OSCAL data to be processed from any of the available formats indicated by the items.

When a resource includes a citation, then the `title` and `citation` properties must both be included.

OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceUuidFlagT.title: Resource Universally Unique Identifier
OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceUuidFlagT.description: A unique identifier for a resource.

OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceTitleFiel.title: Resource Title
OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceTitleFiel.description: An optional name given to the resource, which may be used by a tool for display and navigation.

OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceDescripti.title: Resource Description
OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceDescripti.description: An optional short summary of the resource used to indicate the purpose of the resource.

OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceCitationA.title: Citation
OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceCitationA.description: An optional citation consisting of end note text using structured markup.

OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceRlinkAsse.title: Resource link
OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceRlinkAsse.description:
A URL-based pointer to an external resource with an optional hash for verification and change detection.

Multiple `rlink` objects can be included for a resource. In such a case, all provided `rlink` items are intended to be equivalent in content, but may differ in structure or format.

A `media-type` is used to identify the format of a given rlink, and can be used to differentiate items in a collection of rlinks. The `media-type` provides a hint to the OSCAL document consumer about the structure of the resource referenced by the `rlink`.

OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceRlinkHref.title: Hypertext Reference
OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceRlinkHref.description:
A resolvable URL pointing to the referenced resource.

This value may be either:

1. an [absolute URI](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#absolute-uri) that points to a network resolvable resource,
2. a [relative reference](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/uri-use/#relative-reference) pointing to a network resolvable resource whose base URI is the URI of the containing document, or

OscalMetadataHashFieldType.title: Hash
OscalMetadataHashFieldType.description: A representation of a cryptographic digest generated over a resource using a specified hash algorithm.

OscalMetadataHashAlgorithmFlagType.title: Hash algorithm
OscalMetadataHashAlgorithmFlagType.description:
The digest method by which a hash is derived.

Any other value used MUST be a value defined in the W3C [XML Security Algorithm Cross-Reference](https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlsec-algorithms/#digest-method-uris) Digest Methods (W3C, April 2013) or [RFC 6931 Section 2.1.5](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6931#section-2.1.5) New SHA Functions.

OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceBase64Fie.title: Base64
OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceBase64Fie.description: A resource encoded using the Base64 alphabet defined by [RFC 2045](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2045.html).

OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceBase64Fil.title: File Name
OscalMetadataBackMatterResourceBase64Fil.description: Name of the file before it was encoded as Base64 to be embedded in a `resource`. This is the name that will be assigned to the file when the file is decoded.

OscalCatalogCatalogAssemblyType.title: Catalog
OscalCatalogCatalogAssemblyType.description:
A structured, [organized collection](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/terminology/#catalog) of control information.

Catalogs may use one or more `group` objects to subdivide the control contents of a catalog.

OscalCatalogCatalogUuidFlagType.title: Catalog Universally Unique Identifier
OscalCatalogCatalogUuidFlagType.description: Provides a globally unique means to identify a given catalog instance.

OscalControlCommonParamAssemblyType.title: Parameter
OscalControlCommonParamAssemblyType.description:
Parameters provide a mechanism for the dynamic assignment of value(s) in a control.

In a catalog, a parameter is typically used as a placeholder for the future assignment of a parameter value, although the OSCAL model allows for the direct assignment of a value if desired by the control author. The `value` may be optionally used to specify one or more values. If no value is provided, then it is expected that the value will be provided at the Profile or Implementation layer.

A parameter can include a variety of metadata options that support the future solicitation of one or more values. A `label` provides a textual placeholder that can be used in a tool to solicit parameter value input, or to display in catalog documentation. The `desc` provides a short description of what the parameter is used for, which can be used in tooling to help a user understand how to use the parameter. A `constraint` can be used to provide criteria for the allowed values. A `guideline` provides a recommendation for the use of a parameter.

OscalControlCommonParamIdFlagType.title: Parameter Identifier
OscalControlCommonParamIdFlagType.description: A unique identifier for the parameter.

OscalControlCommonParamClassFlagType.title: Parameter Class
OscalControlCommonParamClassFlagType.description:
A textual label that provides a characterization of the type, purpose, use or scope of the parameter.

A `class` can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of a specific `class` value.

OscalControlCommonParamDependsOnFlagType.title: Depends on
OscalControlCommonParamDependsOnFlagType.description: **(deprecated)** Another parameter invoking this one. This construct has been deprecated and should not be used.

OscalControlCommonParamLabelFieldType.title: Parameter Label
OscalControlCommonParamLabelFieldType.description:
A short, placeholder name for the parameter, which can be used as a substitute for a `value` if no value is assigned.

The label value is intended use when rendering a parameter in generated documentation or a user interface when a parameter is referenced. Note that labels are not required to be distinctive, which means that parameters within the same control may have the same label.

OscalControlCommonParamUsageFieldType.title: Parameter Usage Description
OscalControlCommonParamUsageFieldType.description: Describes the purpose and use of a parameter.

OscalControlCommonParameterConstraintAss.title: Constraint
OscalControlCommonParameterConstraintAss.description: A formal or informal expression of a constraint or test.

OscalControlCommonParameterConstraintDes.title: Constraint Description
OscalControlCommonParameterConstraintDes.description: A textual summary of the constraint to be applied.

OscalControlCommonParameterConstraintTes.title: Constraint Test
OscalControlCommonParameterConstraintTes.description: A test expression which is expected to be evaluated by a tool.

OscalControlCommonParameterConstraintTes.title: Constraint test
OscalControlCommonParameterConstraintTes.description: A formal (executable) expression of a constraint.

OscalControlCommonParameterGuidelineAsse.title: Guideline
OscalControlCommonParameterGuidelineAsse.description: A prose statement that provides a recommendation for the use of a parameter.

OscalControlCommonParameterGuidelinePros.title: Guideline Text
OscalControlCommonParameterGuidelinePros.description: Prose permits multiple paragraphs, lists, tables etc.

OscalControlCommonParameterValueFieldTyp.title: Parameter Value
OscalControlCommonParameterValueFieldTyp.description: A parameter value or set of values.

OscalControlCommonParameterSelectionAsse.title: Selection
OscalControlCommonParameterSelectionAsse.description:
Presenting a choice among alternatives.

A set of parameter value choices, that may be picked from to set the parameter value.

OscalControlCommonParameterSelectionHowM.title: Parameter Cardinality
OscalControlCommonParameterSelectionHowM.description: Describes the number of selections that must occur. Without this setting, only one value should be assumed to be permitted.

OscalControlCommonParameterSelectionChoi.title: Choice
OscalControlCommonParameterSelectionChoi.description: A value selection among several such options.

OscalCatalogControlAssemblyType.title: Control
OscalCatalogControlAssemblyType.description:
A [structured object](https://pages.nist.gov/OSCAL/concepts/terminology/#control) representing a requirement or guideline, which when implemented will reduce an aspect of risk related to an information system and its information.

Each security or privacy control within the catalog is defined by a distinct control instance. Controls may be as complex or as simple as a catalog defines them. They may be decomposed or further specified into child `control` objects, for example to represent control enhancements or specific breakouts of control functionality, to be maintained as discrete requirements. Controls may also contain structured parts (using `part`) and they may be grouped together in families or classes with `group`.

Control structures in OSCAL will also exhibit regularities and rules that are not codified in OSCAL but in its applications or domains of application. For example, for catalogs describing controls as defined by NIST SP 800-53, a control must have a part with the name "statement", which represents the textual narrative of the control. This "statement" part must occur only once, but may have nested parts to allow for multiple paragraphs or sections of text. This organization supports addressability of this data content as long as, and only insofar as, it is consistently implemented across the control set. As given with these model definitions, constraints defined and assigned here can aid in ensuring this regularity; but other such constraints and other useful patterns of use remain to be discovered and described.

OscalCatalogControlIdFlagType.title: Control Identifier
OscalCatalogControlIdFlagType.description: Identifies a control such that it can be referenced in the defining catalog and other OSCAL instances (e.g., profiles).

OscalCatalogControlClassFlagType.title: Control Class
OscalCatalogControlClassFlagType.description:
A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the control.

A `class` can be used in validation rules to express extra
constraints over named items of a specific `class`
value.

A `class` can also be used in an OSCAL profile as a means to
target an alteration to control content.

OscalCatalogControlTitleFieldType.title: Control Title
